conversations_v0.question: In the diagram, quadrilateral ABCD is a rhombus. Can you determine the measure of angle ADB if CE is the perpendicular bisector of side AB? Choices: A: 20° B: 25° C: 30° D: 40°
conversations_v0.answer: As seen in the diagram, connect AC. Given that quadrilateral ABCD is a rhombus, it has four equal sides, meaning AB = BC = CD = DA. Since CE is the perpendicular bisector of side AB, triangle ACE and triangle BCE are right triangles. This makes AC equal to BC as well. Hence, triangle ABC turns into an isosceles triangle where AB = AC = BC. Given that triangle ABC is isosceles with equal sides and angles, each of the base angles (angle BAC and angle BCA) measures 60°, implying angle ABC is 60°. Therefore, angle ABD equals 30° due to the properties of the rhombus and bisectors. Consequently, angle ADB, being equal to angle ABD, also measures 30°. Hence, the answer is: C.

conversations_v0.question: Compare a rhombus to a rectangle in terms of their mathematical properties and practical uses.
conversations_v0.answer: While both rhombus and rectangle are quadrilaterals, they have different properties. A rhombus has all sides of equal length, while a rectangle has all angles equal to 90 degrees. Practically, rectangles are more common in construction due to their straightforward right-angle design that simplifies building layouts. Rhombuses, on the other hand, provide unique aesthetic and structural benefits, especially in design elements requiring uniform distribution and symmetry.
